ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

INCOME DISPARITY


    The following Question Nos. 1 and 2 stood in the name of Mr Yeo Guat Kwang -

    1. To ask the Minister for Trade and Industry how his Ministry interprets the 1999 Labour Force Survey which showed an increasing trend in income disparity; and what plans the Government has to help the unskilled, lower-income workers to improve their job prospect.

    2. To ask the Minister for Trade and Industry how his Ministry interprets the 1999 Labour Force Survey which showed a rise in income inequality; and what social safety nets are available to help the lowest-income households avoid hardship.

    3. Dr Lily Neo asked the Minister for Trade and Industry whether any further constructive steps have been taken by the Government to render assistance to the bottom 10% of the population whose household income had plummeted.

    4. Mr Tay Beng Chuan asked the Minister for Trade and Industry whether his Ministry will quickly identify the bottom 10% of our population with an average monthly household income of only $133.00 and encourage them to take up the many better-paid unskilled jobs

Column: 371

that our small and medium enterprises are desperately trying to fill up to meet the demand in the service, retail and manufacturing sectors.

    5. Dr Jennifer Lee asked the Minister for Trade and Industry whether single-parent families and other family structures not within our "traditional" definition form a disproportionate number of the households in the lowest-income group and, if so, whether the Government will review its policies to help these families bridge the income divide.

    Dr Lily Neo (Kreta Ayer-Tanglin): Question No. 1, Sir.

    The Minister for Trade and Industry (BG George Yong-Boon Yeo): Mr Speaker, Sir, may I have your permission to take Question Nos. 1 to 5 together, please?

    Mr Speaker: Yes.

    BG George Yong-Boon Yeo: The Government has always been committed to helping low income families improve their economic prospects and living standard. First, we ensure that their basic needs are met through affordable housing and healthcare. Second, we help equip them with the means to support themselves by providing heavily subsidised education and skills training. Third, we help create ample job opportunities by building a strong and competitive economy.

    This approach has worked well for us. Over the years, low income families in Singapore have seen their incomes and living standard rise steadily, in real terms.

    Among households in the bottom 20%, 95% own colour TV sets, 90% own telephones, and 77% own washing machines. These ownership rates are better than even the national average of all households in many developing countries.

    Our achievement in home ownership is also good. While many of the poor in other countries are homeless, the lowest 20% of

Column: 372

households in Singapore are well-housed. 75% of them own their own homes.

    We have achieved this without creating dependence or weakening the family, and in a way which gives opportunity and hope for the children of low income families to do better. All segments of our society are thus able to benefit from our economic prosperity, and this is part of the reason for Singapore's political stability.

    Given the progress we have made, many people were surprised and disturbed by newspaper headlines claiming that the lowest 10% of our households lived on only $133 a month. In fact, the headlines were misleading and inaccurate.

    The Department of Statistics had reported that, in 1999, the average income from work of the bottom 10% of households was $133 per month. This was the statistical average. 75% of these households had members who did not work at all and therefore reported zero income. This pulled down the average income for this group of households to $133 per month.

    This statistical average of $133 per month in 1999 was sharply lower than the average of $258 per month in 1998. The main reason was that the proportion of households in the bottom 10% with no working persons went up from 62% in 1998 to 75% in 1999. Put it another way, the proportion of households with persons working fell sharply from more than one-third (38%) to one-quarter.

    This was partly because unemployment increased during the regional economic crisis, and also because the number of retiree households had grown. (The proportion of retiree households in the bottom 10% has risen from 27% in 1997 to 32% in 1998 and 35% in 1999*.) [*The increase in retiree households can be attributed to (a) the ageing population, and (b) older workers choosing to retire due to the poor job opportunities during the economic crisis.] Dr Jennifer Lee asked whether there is a disproportionate number of the households in the lowest-income group which are single-parent families. Single parent

Column: 373

families constituted only 4.2% of households in the bottom 10% in 1999*. [*Definied as households with heads who are: (a) single, widowed, divorced/separated; and (b) with children below 16 years of age. The percentage of single parent households in the bottom 10%, although low, is higher than the national average of 1.8%.] This was in fact a slight reduction from the 4.5% in 1998.

    To cushion the impact of the crisis on the lower income families, the Government had provided rebates in HDB rental, utilities and service and conservancy charges as part of the cost cutting package. This assistance amounted to about $46 per month for households in HDB 1- and 2-room flats, and $36 per month for those in HDB 3-room flats.

    Mr Tay Beng Chuan has suggested that we help the bottom 10% take up the many better-paid unskilled jobs that our small and medium enterprises (SMEs) are trying to fill. The Ministry of Manpower (MOM) provides employment assistance, at no charge, to unemployed Singaporeans who have difficulties finding a job, including those in the bottom 10%. It actively sources for job vacancies, and organises job fairs and outplacement events in partnership with employers, unions, and the Community Development Councils. SMEs seeking workers are encouraged to register their job offers with MOM and participate in its recruitment events.

    As the economy recovers and the job market improves, more people in the bottom 10% would be able to find employment and the income growth of working households should resume.

    For the bottom 10% of households, their median CPF savings amounted to $20,000 in 1999. Among them, only 25% live in 1- or 2- room HDB flats. 39% live in HDB 3-room flats, 24% in 4-room or larger flats and 11% in private properties. Nearly all of these are owner-occupied.

    In other words, many in the bottom 10% have significant wealth, in the form of CPF savings and their homes. They are not an underclass.

Column: 374



    I have taken some time to put the Department of Statistics' figures in context, as it is important that we get a right picture of the bottom 10% income households before we discuss how best to help them. There are poor Singaporeans in our midst but the situation is not at all as bad as the headlines portrayed. To help the less well-off, the Government has put in place a range of assistance programmes.

    The Ministry of Community Development and Sports (MCDS) has various schemes that target the most disadvantaged in our society. The Public Assistance (PA) Scheme provides long term financial help. PA recipients also receive free medical services and assistance in-kind. The Interim Financial Assistance Scheme caters to those in need of shorter term help, while families in rental flats can seek relief from the Rental and Utilities Assistance Scheme (RUAS). There are also child care and student care fee assistance schemes for low-income families. The Community Development Councils (CDCs) further complement these schemes with other assistance tailored for their needy residents.

    For the children of low income families, the Ministry of Education (MOE) renders help for their education. MOE's Financial Assistance Scheme (FAS) provides needy pupils from families receiving social assistance from MCDS a 50% waiver of miscellaneous fees, full waiver of school fees and a textbook grant or an annual bursary. Schools can augment the assistance through the School Advisory Committee or School Management Committee Fund. Children from low-income families who perform well are also awarded Edusave Merit Bursaries. Many charitable foundations and grassroots organisations provide supplementary support.

    In the area of healthcare, the Ministry of Health (MOH) ensures that healthcare remains affordable and accessible to all,

Column: 375

including the poor. Class C wards are subsidised 80%. Patients facing difficulty in paying their healthcare bills are assisted by the Medifund scheme.

    In addition, the Government also funds 90% of the capital expenditure and 50% of the recurrent expenditure of approved projects by social service agencies. This enables community organisations to provide a support system, such as counselling services or simple financial budgeting guidance, for families in need which go beyond just dollars and cents. Together with the National Council of Social Service, MCDS is also encouraging more corporations to sponsor assistance programmes for the less fortunate. This `many helping hands' approach enables us to create a strong basic social safety net for the poor.

    Looking ahead, the bigger concern to us is the widening income gap between the bottom and top earners. The average income ratio of the top 20% to the bottom 20% households has increased from 13.6 times in 1997 to 17.9 times in 1999. This was partly because the impact of the recent recession was much harder on the lower income households than on the higher income households. However, it is also likely to indicate a longer-term structural trend.

    With globalisation, there is now a global market for labour. At the top, scarce talents command high international wages while, at the bottom, the wages earned by those who are unskilled come under increasing downward pressure from the hundreds of millions in the Third World joining the global market who are prepared to work for a pittance. This is a worldwide trend which our system of foreign worker levies ameliorate only to a point.

    In the US, the ratio of average income of the top 20% to bottom 20% increased

Column: 376

from 12.2 in 1988 to 13.7 in 1998. According to a recent report in the International Herald Tribune, the income gap in the US is now at its widest since data was collected in 1977*, [*Study by the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities was based on after-tax income figures from the Congressional Budget Office. Source: IHT, 6 September 1999.] with the ratio of top executives' to factory workers' pay increased 10-fold from 42 times in 1980, to 419 times in 1998*. [*By the Institute for Policy Studies and United for a Fair Economy. Source: IHT, 6 September 1999.] Even in Japan, which has long been regarded as one of the world's most egalitarian industrialized nations, the gap between the rich and poor is widening*. [*Source: IHT, 5 January 2000.] We can expect the same to happen in Singapore.

    What should be our response? First, we must make sure that the incomes of those at the bottom continue to rise. We can only achieve this if our economy continues to grow healthily. For the majority of low-income Singaporeans, especially older and less educated workers, skills upgrading is the key to enhancing employability and income. The Ministry of Manpower has therefore worked with employers and unions to launch the Skills Redevelopment Programme (SRP). Under the SRP, generous grants covering up to 100% of course fees and 85% of absentee payroll are provided for the training of less educated workers aged 40 years and above. The target is to upgrade the skills of some 100,000 workers through this programme by the year 2003.

    In addition, the Ministry of Manpower is working with other Government economic agencies and employers to professionalise jobs in domestic-based industries with low productivity such as cleaning, construction and retail. The aim is to upgrade these jobs to achieve higher skill content, and facilitate the training or retraining of workers in these industries. With improved productivity, these industries can then provide more viable job opportunities for local workers, including those displaced as a result of economic restructuring. To support the various manpower development initiatives, the Government has set aside $200 million

Column: 377

for the Manpower Development Assistance Scheme to co-fund the projects with industries.

    Second, we must continue to ensure that lower income families have the means and opportunities to move up the economic and social ladder. That is to say, we must have as little friction as possible to social mobility and progression. Here, our education system plays a crucial role. We must give every child the best education possible and prepare him for the needs of the New Economy. This is why we have always given the highest emphasis to education. For every cohort, we are targeting 25% to have a university education, 40% to have a polytechnic education and another 25% to have an ITE education. We make sure that the children of poor families are not disadvantaged. MOE, MCDS and the CDCs help them financially so that no child is prevented from being educated to the limit of his potential because his parents are poor, sick or unemployed.

    As Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong has pointed out, our basic approach is to level up. The more economic growth we have, the more we will be able to level upwards. The key is a healthy Singapore economy that is globally competitive.

    Our social safety net sets a good minimum standard of living for the least well-off Singaporeans. This undergirds our sense of community solidarity. Beyond that, we must always give hope to those at the bottom that even if they themselves cannot do better, their children will be able to. At all times, our system must incentivise effort, family support and self-help.

    Dr Lily Neo: May I ask the Minister whether there will be newer incentives, apart from those mentioned earlier, to facilitate low-paid and low-skilled workers to go for further training so that they can earn more wages?

    BG George Yong-Boon Yeo: These are on-going programmes. We have allocated funds for them. As and when new needs

Column: 378

come up, we will look at how these new needs can be met, and if we have to allocate more funds for such undertakings, we will do so.

    Mr Heng Chiang Meng (Cheng San): I would like to ask the Minister to review other aspects of this issue which affects the ability of lower income Singaporeans to improve their financial situation. May I ask that he looks into the various Government policies which, though well-conceived and implemented with good intent, have the unintended effect of disadvantaging the lower income groups' ability to improve themselves. For example, would the Minister review the policy of prohibiting the sale of cooked food prepared in homes? Would the Minister consider reinstating the past policy of allocating hawker stalls and school tuckshop stalls to deserving applicants instead of tendering them to the highest bidders?

    Sir, these are some of the traditional ways in which the poor could improve their financial situation but today they are no longer available because of Government policies. Would the Minister also review HDB's policy of not permitting second-time direct purchases from HDB if the second unit is of a lower category from the first even though both purchases could be within HDB's general policy of two direct purchases from HDB? Surely, the removal ---

    Mr Speaker: Order. Mr Heng, are you making a speech?

    Mr Heng Chiang Meng: No, Sir, I am asking questions. I am asking: whether the Minister could do this or do that. These are all questions.

    Mr Speaker: I know that. But you are also punctuating your questions with sentences.

    Mr Heng Chiang Meng: I agree. I will remove the sentences.

    Mr Speaker: All right.

    Mr Heng Chiang Meng: Sir, I would like to ask the Minister whether he could

Column: 379

establish an Inter-Ministry Committee to review and amend, if needed, such policies, taking into consideration the effect on the poor and the diminishing number of opportunities for them to upgrade themselves. I would also like to ask the Minister that if he does so, whether feedback from the public would be solicited.

    BG George Yong-Boon Yeo: Sir, I thank Mr Heng for his helpful suggestions. Some of the issues are not new issues, like whether we should allow cooked food to be prepared in HDB households. There are, of course, conflicting objectives because there are externalities involved. The smoke may cause annoyance to neighbours and we should strike a proper balance between allowing for flexibility of resource allocation and not causing inconveniences or negative externalities to people around. But these are issues which Ministries should review from time to time so that we are not trapped in old positions, especially with the new challenges posed by changes in the world. His particular suggestions will be forwarded to the various Ministries for their consideration.

    Dr Lily Neo: May I ask the Minister whether the widening of income gap in Singapore is definitely getting worse and whether this will jeopardize social cohesion, social stability and other related issues here?

    BG George Yong-Boon Yeo: The most common index used by countries to measure inequality of income is the gini coefficient and the higher it is, the greater the inequality. For many years, before the economic crisis, our gini coefficient has improved and then flattened out. During the crisis year of 1998, it went up. So we asked ourselves whether this was just the result of the economic crisis which hit those at the bottom disproportionately or whether it represented a trend break. We have been studying the gini coefficient in advanced countries in the US, the OECD and so on, and we have noted that in these countries, the gini coefficient has tended to worsen. So we ask ourselves: what is the likely tendency in the future? I

Column: 380

think we have worsened because of globalisation. The top in our social ladder would command international wages, particularly in growth sectors where talents are scarce. Many of our hotshot dot.com types now command fabulous salaries or incomes because of the recent boom. Of course, the bubble has punctured the boom somewhat but, still, relative to many other sectors, they have done very well.

    Then there are those who are unskilled and, increasingly, they are competing with the unskilled in China, Vietnam, Indonesia and India. With the end of the Cold War, these countries are opening up and hundreds of millions of people are entering the workplace. In the past, when they lived in remote villages, they could not compete in the global market. Now, with better communication, transportation, Internet and e-commerce, more and more of them are entering the global market and this has a depressing effect on the wages which unskilled labour in Singapore can command. Of course, in the services sector, they tend to be protected. But even in the services sector, with the globalisation trends, more and more segments in the services sector are being opened up to global competitive pressure and it is in our own interest to open up the services sector to international competition because it lowers the cost of doing business in Singapore and helps make the tradable sector more competitive.

    Will the worsening of the gini coefficient continue forever? I think in the end, it will find its own equilibrium. When a new frontier is opened, there are the robber barons, there are those who have struck gold, and there are those who are left penurious, so the coefficient tends to widen. But after a while, stability will resume. Those who are at the bottom will catch up, those who are at the top will find that temporary scarcity is met by growing supply, and so the trend may reverse itself years down the road. But when that will take place, we do not know because the economic changes taking the world today are truly revolutionary.

    Mr Low Thia Khiang (Hougang): The Minister mentioned the Government's

Column: 381

target to upgrade 100,000 less-educated workers by 2003. I would like to know from the Minister what are the targets of this group of workers specifically and what concrete steps the Government has taken so far to achieve these targets. Also, is the Minister aware of the problems of these low-educated, low-paid workers, many of whom are trapped in low-paid professions? And will the Government consider providing a living allowance to these workers who are prepared to go for training? The other question is: in view of the widening income gap, will the Government review the benchmark for affordability in terms of HDB flats and healthcare services?

    BG George Yong-Boon Yeo: The Skills Redevelopment Programme covers a wide range of retraining courses. It is true that among the older workers, some find it hard even to get themselves retrained in these courses. But we have had some very good successes of workers going for retraining and finding good jobs in growth sectors of the economy. Take, for instance, our disk-drive industry which has shed thousands of workers in the last two years. Many of these workers had since been redeployed to other industry sectors.     Based on the latest figures for the existing benchmarks, the Superscale G annual salary should be $363,000, 50% more than the current $242,000. The Staff Grade I annual salary should be $1.64 million, about 90% more than the current $861,000.

    We have found that the benchmark of 15P32 for Superscale G is sound. It has been effective in attracting and retaining good officers in the Administrative Service for the past 5 years. We will retain the benchmark as it is.

    In the case of the 2/3 AVE24 benchmark, the basic approach of comparing the salaries of Ministers and senior civil servants with a basket of top earners in the 6 professions is sound. The 6 professions remain relevant and appropriate, and the discount factor of 2/3 is reasonable. Empirically, the benchmark has been reliable, moving in line with wider trends of earnings of top professionals.

    However, the robustness of the 2/3 AVE24 benchmark can be improved in several respects. Firstly, the base of the benchmark is narrow. Only the 4 highest earners are chosen from each profession. These 4 may not be representative of top members of the profession, but may just be the few individuals who happened to have had an exceptionally good year.

    Secondly, the benchmark uses the arithmetic average of the 24 incomes. In other words, we get the 24 figures, we add them together, we divide by 24 and use that average. The average is satisfactory if the 24 incomes are clustered fairly close together. But if there are a few extremely high incomes in the group, this will affect the average, and will make the average less representative of the group as a whole.

    Therefore, instead of using the arithmetic average, we will take the median income of the group, ie, the 24th highest income among the group of 48. We have 48 people. We rank them from the highest to bottom and we choose the 24th person, who is in the middle, and we use that as the representative. This fixed rank approach will not be skewed by the presence of a few very high income earners, and will yield a more stable benchmark. Because I am choosing the income of person number 24, so even if person number 1 earns $10 million instead of $2 million, it does not affect that figure of the middle person unless the whole group moves, in which case it is fair for the median and our benchmark also to move.

    Earlier this afternoon, Members debated a full hour on the widening income gap. The numbers that were released by DPM BG Lee puts this in sharp focus. Members

Column: 437

will observe how much the income gap has widened in top talent and the workers in the factory. This trend, however, is not a Singapore phenomenon. I have been associated with the trade unions for 20 years. It is my job to see how others pay workers elsewhere and what incomes were like between management and workers. I know that this trend has its origins in the United States. In the 1980s, US companies restructured and re-engineered to regain the competitiveness they had lost to other MNCs, particularly the Japanese. One of the key changes they made was to provide new and attractive incentive schemes to top executives, the most significant of which are stock options. The stock option message is clear. If you make the company grow, your share in it grows as well.

    By the 1990s, US companies had regained their vitality. New ideas emerged, using new technology. As the revitalised US companies sweep the competition, MNCs elsewhere followed these successful United States models. In Europe, the United Kingdom led the way and these methods are now spreading in Western Europe. Indeed, there is an on-going debate raging in some continental European countries steeped in socialist thinking. They ask: are the wages of top earners obscene? European MNCs are not waiting for the conclusion of this debate - they have to survive, and therefore, they are fighting for their share of top talent who will make a difference to their future.

    What is the result? Under the administration of Tony Blair's New Labour, the income gap in the United Kingdom is now wider than it ever was during the Thatcher years!

    French Socialist Finance Minister, Laurent Fabius could not persuade one top talent he wanted to join and work for him. Why? He was locked up by his company with stock options!

    And the Japanese have taken notice. They too, are beginning to embrace

Column: 438

American methods. They have started to employ non-Japanese to lead their troubled companies and I am sure that they must pay top wages to get those foreigners to work for Japanese companies.

    Some people ask: can we stop the income gap from widening? In other words, let the Americans and the Europeans and even the Japanese go their way and let us go our way. This is unrealistic. We cannot buck the trend. Ours is rated as the most globalised economy by one research company, AT Kearney reported in The Economist. Therefore, what happens elsewhere will come to pass here as well. Our top talent will compete for jobs at top first world wages. Go to New York, Silicon Valley, London, Hong Kong or Tokyo - you will find some of our best talents there. They are paid what top talents in the world are paid. Many of them earn several millions a year and they do so quietly.

    Do we want more of our top talent leaving to join first world companies? Are we satisfied that they do well in the first world countries, creating jobs there? Or do we want them here, developing companies, creating jobs for Singaporeans? I think we want the latter.

    Fortunately, we still have most of our top talent here. But try to narrow the income gap here by imposing a limit on top end wages instead of letting market forces work - we will merely see the migration of our top talent. The cost would be a sluggish economy, higher unemployment and lower wages across the board, not just low wages at the top, but lower wages also at the bottom. Far from helping the lower income, we will be consigning them to third world standards of living.

Column: 439

will say that the wealth of the country is not due just to the efforts of Government or the civil service but due to the hard-work of the people of Singapore. True, I agree but our hardworking people need leaders to show them the right way. If we do not have top talent to analyse the problems we face and devise the right policies and plans, all their hard work will be in vain.

    I made my first of several trips to Vietnam in 1992. I was deeply impressed by how motivated and hardworking the Vietnamese people are. They had abandoned the centrally-planned economy, where everyone was paid almost the same low wages, for the market economy, following what other communist countries had done.

    I made my most recent trip two weeks ago. One Vietnamese asked what I think of Vietnam. Well, there has been progress. Some Vietnamese are better off. They drive cars or motorcycles. Their traffic jams in the evenings are not due just to bicycles but also to many motorcycles. But they could have done a lot better, if their leaders have been bolder in accepting market-oriented policies. They could have attracted more investments creating jobs in Vietnam. Instead, today they are planning to export 300,000 workers overseas, the solution which Mr Zulkifli might have suggested for our lower income and low-skilled workers. But I do not think that is the way to go, because to send our low-skilled workers overseas means paying them wages of third world countries. They get a better pay working here in Singapore. Vietnamese workers, I think, toil harder than Singaporean workers but they do not enjoy the quality of life our workers have.

    What is the difference? It is in the quality of leadership - in Government and in the civil service. Without capable leaders showing the right way, our workers can work hard but see no improvement in their lives. I do not mean to criticise the Vietnamese government. The transition from a centrally-planned economy to a market economy is not an easy one. But the point is: hard work by the people alone is not enough; the policies must be right.

Column: 440



    We do not want Singaporeans to toil hard for little return. We want them to have good jobs here. We want them to be better skilled, more productive and earning higher wages.

    While our economic recovery is firm, let us not underestimate the problems that we face. The transition that we have to make into the knowledge economy is not an easy one. At the same time, many of the jobs we now have are under threat.

    We have done well in a number of areas. But this success does not guarantee the future. We have to draw a lesson from the Fortune Top 100 list. In 20 years, the names at the top are quite different! So even in the sectors where we are rated among the best, we can be left behind.

    Take, for example, the port of Singapore. It has been our lifeline since the founding of modern Singapore. In recent years, we have seen how new ports close by can pose a real challenge to PSA.

    Take Changi Airport. It has developed into the leading hub in the region, even though, geographically, Bangkok is better sited. But this position may not last forever. Two days ago, I flew back from London. The Singapore Airlines flight was almost full. However, most of the passengers did not stop over in Singapore. The majority changed to connecting flights to Australia. Good business for SIA and Changi Airport, but not our hotels or shops. The same day (27th June) at noon, I read in the New Paper that with the new Boeing 747-400 and flight paths over China, Qantas can fly London-Sydney refuelling at Bangkok, cutting one hour from the journey.

    That is only the harbinger of things to come. In a few short years, a new generation of aircraft can fly London-Sydney non-stop. So will most of those who commute between Europe and Australia over fly Singapore?

    Will Changi face the same fate as Honolulu? Honolulu used to be a stop-over for trans-Pacific flights, but aircraft now fly non-stop across the Pacific. Will Changi face the same fate as

Column: 441

airports in the Middle East, once a necessary stop between Asia and Europe? What implications have this development for Singapore Airlines? What new strategies must it adopt to remain one of the leading airlines in the world, maintaining 25,000 jobs it creates, mostly for Singaporeans, and we are not talking about jobs for the lower 10% of Singaporeans. We are talking about good jobs.

    Take another example: the telecommunications sector. Technology has changed so fast in this sector, and the ground rules have likewise changed. Today SingTel has a tough challenge to remain a national champion generating thousands of good jobs for Singaporeans. In order to strengthen our chances of remaining our telecommunications hub in the region, we have opened up the sector, adding greater pressure on SingTel. Better to open up, create jobs for Singaporeans, even if they work for foreign companies, than to continue to protect SingTel and risk losing everything.

    These are but three examples. They show that we are not just competing with countries in the region, we are competing globally. Therefore, we need to get the best talent in Government, in the civil service and in our leading companies.

    If US companies, European companies and, most likely, also the Japanese companies all pay top wages for top talent, we will see top end wages here rise as well, if we are to retain and attract our share of talent to tackle the new challenges before us.

    The income gap may widen, but it will widen because wages will rise much more slowly at the lower end. But it does not mean that there is no improvement in the lives of those at the bottom.

    Will the income gap stop widening? At this stage of our development, it will widen further, but it will slow down. Even in the United States, the gap will not widen indefinitely. It must also plateau off, even swing back and narrow somewhat.

Column: 442

Indeed, the dip in the Dow Jones index and Nasdaq recently has, in many instances, reduced the variable payments top executives get. One day it may be a more prolonged dip. If that happens, it will happen here as well. When that will be, it is difficult to predict.

    Our task is to get people in Government and in the civil service to devise policies that will ensure that the low income share in the progress of the country, even with their relatively lower incomes. It means successfully attracting investments to create good jobs for all our workers. It means keeping HDB flats affordable, ensuring that good healthcare is available to everyone, that children from all families get the best education they deserve. For now, we have to follow the world-wide trend and pay top talent the high wages they can earn elsewhere. But more of the annual wage for them should be variable, as in the private sector. I am pleased that the new wage structure that DPM BG Lee announced matches more closely private sector practice.

    Apart from ensuring that our workers continue to have good jobs, and their families continue to enjoy a decent life, we must maintain equal opportunities for all, irrespective of family income. This has been so throughout our short history. The children of poor families have been able to go all the way to university, and then into jobs. It is still so today.

    When I left for London recently, one SATS employee, a Muslim woman, assisted my mother-in-law with a wheelchair, pushing her to the boarding gate. I had a casual conversation with her, and found that she was going on leave next month - on holiday to Canada. It pleased me that an ordinary worker of SATS can afford to take a holiday so far away. But what pleased me much more was her telling me that she would be visiting her son who is there studying to become a doctor. So our system today allows children from humble families to rise to the top! We must make sure that this remains so. And even if we may have to live with a higher income disparity than we have been comfortable with, we know

Column: 443

that in the next generation, the children from low-income families also have a chance to get to the top, and draw top wages.

    So our policies must not only ensure everyone has a good job, a comfortable home and access to healthcare, we must also ensure that our education system remains a social leveller that gives every child equal opportunities to go as far as his abilities allow him or her.

    Sir, I have taken this line in this debate because I know there is a lot of concern for the plight of the low-income. There is concern about this sense of unhappiness seeing others earn top wages, and that maybe the solution could be to narrow the income gap. But to me, after 20 years working with the trade unions, I know that the best way to help the low-income is to ensure that they have a job, that they can earn a living and hold their heads high. And that way is to make sure that we have top talent in Government, in the civil service and also in our companies.

extremely heavy responsibility of formulating and implementing public policies, are of the best calibre. They must be better than those personnel in the private sector. have both a good Government and a very efficient civil service. This is indeed most commendable.

the impression that they might not get the money if they were to go there late. The staff from CPF Board manifested their care and concern for these old folks. Column: 453

in the economic growth and social development of the country. The reverse is true. GDP-related Bonus

    The GDP-related bonus will directly link the pay of political and statutory appointment holders and senior Administrative Officers to the state of the economy.

    The size of the bonus will depend on the real economic growth of the economy. The bonus will be 1 month if the Singapore economy grows by 5% in the calendar year, the mid-point of its estimated long-term growth potential (4 - 6%). It will be 0 month (the minimum) if the economy grows by 2% or less, and 2 months (the maximum) if the economy grows by 8% or more. In between, it will vary linearly with GDP growth.

    The intention is to eventually build up this bonus to an average of 3 months, with a range of 0-6 months.

Performance Bonus

    Performance bonuses were first introduced for Superscale officers in the Administrative Service in 1989. Since then, they have been extended to timescale Administrative Officers as well.

    The performance bonus norms will be raised as follows:

    Political and statutory appointment holders and Administrative Officers in Superscale C and above presently receive performance bonuses averaging 4 months of salary. This will be increased to an average of 5 months for those in Salary Range SR6 and above.

    Administrative Officers up to Superscale D1 presently receive between 1 - 2 months of performance bonus on average, depending on their grades. This will be increased to an average of between 3 - 4 months.

    How many months of performance bonus an officer actually receives will vary from person to person. Those with unsatisfactory performance will receive no bonus at all, while an outstanding officer will receive much more than the average quantum.

    Several appointments currently receive fixed bonuses instead of a performance bonus: the President, PM, SM, Chief Justice, Speaker, Chairman PSC, Attorney General and Auditor General. This will continue under the revised framework. Their fixed bonus rate will be set at the average rate for senior officers.

Bonus Pool

    Under the bonus pool system, an officer will be paid half his performance bonus for the year immediately. The Government will contribute the other half into a bonus pool. The officer will be entitled to receive the amount in the bonus pool in two equal instalments 12 and 24 months later, provided he continues in Service.

    Officers who resign or are dismissed from the Service will not be allowed to withdraw any balance in the pool. However, officers who retire from the Service will be allowed to withdraw the balance.

    The bonus pool system will not apply for the President, statutory appointment holders and judicial appointees.
